SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

1. Your full name .............................................. WILLIAM HENRY ISMOND
2. Your address ................................................... 603 1/2 ST. ABERTHEA, ONT.
3. Date ............................................................... APRIL 6, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ......................... CANADA
5. What was your father's name and occupation? ........................................ FARMER
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) ................. MARCH 26, 1892
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. .......................................................... ONTARIO 1891
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.) .................................................. 22 YRS.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? ............................................. To be in my condition.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Rail road or government information?) .................................................. Through people and reading.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Very much opposed to it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   Alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Four of us were unable to get a seat on the train - and stood up all the length of the evening we were able to put a berth, but had only newspapers for a mattress.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   The first night I stayed with Will Wright's family. Next day I went out & looked for a job and got work - hiring to farm a year with a farmer, W.M. Younger for $200. For two years, I farmed a year with a farmer, W.M. Younger for $200.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   I bought a half section of land in 1917. I bought another half section. The location of these farms is not mentioned.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   While in Ontario - at fourteen from that time I was fourteen years old I worked away from home on farms. For a short time I worked building railroad grades. After coming west - I worked for a farmer until buying my own land.
II. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family), friends or other groups? Alone

13. What means of transportation did you use? Train

II. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Train - and stood up all night - got off tired

14. How much money did you have when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

While in Ontario - worked on railroad - 14 years old - worked from dawn to dark - helped build railway - 89 years old - worked for a farmer until after coming west - I worked my own land
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   About three times a year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Wife's maiden name - Emma Eliza Anderson.
   Married Dec. 11, 1873, at Kansas City, Mo.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Four "Glen's" brothers who came neighbors in Ontario.
   Nathaniel Glen was a member of the Saskatchewan government while Mr. Anderson was Premier.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   3 brothers - Francis Wesley Donald - came in 1871 - settled on the south half of Sec. 14, T. 15 R. 2 W.
   Thomas Donald - came in 1871 - settled on the north half of Sec. 14, T. 15 R. 2 W.
   James Donald - came in 1871 - settled on Sec. 14, T. 15 R. 2 W.
   My parents - came in 1871 - lived with the same.
   A niece and nephew - Lucille Hume - who is married and living at Guelph.
   Fred Hume - who lives at home.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   The 2½ months that I worked on the railroad grade road out very clearly - it was no Sunday school picnic. To get to Weyburn, where we started to work, we traveled across the prairie. There were ten wagons. They were no trail and we traveled by compass. There were no buildings after we got six miles beyond Indian Head - we did not see another building until we returned here.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   I traveled by horse and buggy a great deal in the early days.
   I went in 1901 from Leslie's Hill through the Rocky Mountain Country (Cochrane Valley).
   I went in 1906 by train to Swift Current, where I lived for many years.
   I left Swift Current on a Monday morning and drove through the Grass Lake district until Saturday night. I bought 2 acres of land there, which I sold later.
   I traveled through the Stanley district by horse and buggy and bought a section of land there, which I later sold.
   We were ½ mile from church and drove or walked there twice each Sunday, and also to Christian Endeavor meetings during the week.
   We did a great deal of visiting friends in the district - within a mile.
   I went as a delegate to Regina and Guelph to Christian Endeavor Conferences in the years 1896 and 1897 respectively.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About three times a year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatoon because of your recommendation? It was a place to settle?

Matthew Guiney came to Saskatoon because he knew Mr. Anderson and Mr. Guiney.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My family came to Saskatoon in 1897 and lived there until 1914.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

The first winter was very hard. We had no shelter and we traveled all over the Prairies.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

Traveling was very difficult. We traveled by horse and buggy and then by train. In 1916 we traveled from South Porcupine to North Porcupine by train.
No. 24 (Cont'd). We often went to picnics. I belonged to the Kerlis Football Team from the first year I was in the West—1892. I remember going to Pheasant Forks to a picnic that summer of 1892—and playing football there. Pheasant Forks is five miles north of Lemberg—about 20 miles from Kerlis. The same year we played at a school picnic north of Sintaluta.

I remember attending a picnic at Elkhorn in the Tri-Appelte Valley—around 1900. A man in the crowd called out—"Anyone here from Bruce County?" Someone answered: "Yep." "Lend us your cork-screw" called the first man. We often went to Lake Katepwa & picnics. Each summer we drove to the Tri-Appelte valley to pick saskatoons.
No. 24 (Cont'd). We often went to picnic.

I belonged to the X'th football team from the first year I was in the Wear - 1892.

I remember going to Pheasant Forks to a picnic that summer of 1892 and playing football there.

Pheasant Forks is five miles north of Lumbury - about 20 miles from Kenosha. The same year we played at a school picnic north of Milwaukee.

I remember attending a picnic at Silver Lake in the Apple Valley - around 1900.

A man in the crowd called out - "Anyone here from Brown County?" Someone answered: "Yeah."

"Send us your cork screws" called the first man.

We often went to Bob Hattaway's picnic.

Several summers we drove to

An apple valley to pick apples.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? - At first Indian Head - 13 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Very rarely.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? After 1905.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

Some clothing bought from catalogues - but most of our buying was from local merchants.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? In 1909. We had the Keilio Telephone Co., organized by local farmers. They were supplied with telephones. The company purchased the materials and helped to line.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? I made up my mind after I was here for awhile.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Our family were active in church organizations. In 1895 I was given an honorary license by the Methodist Church. I was on the Church Board for about 35 years—ad sec. also for most of the time. My wife was church organized for many years before and after marriage and also taught Sunday School, and was president of the Ladies Aid. I also served a term on the School Board. My wife also served on the School Board. I was active (together with Hon. W. R. MacKenzie, Mrs. MacKenzie, John Miller and others) in organizing the Grain Growers Association—I helped organize the Athabasca Agricultural Association and was always a member. I was made a Life Member in 1950.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I helped organize the "Royal Templars" lodge at Kinloch in 1893. I had the first electric light plant in the district—installed in 1912. Also the first water system—installed in 1920.

39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

My wife, Mrs. W. H. Sommerville, wrote a history of the Kenora District, names of settlers, and description of homesteads, also information about the Post Office and School District. This was sent to the Archives Department.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

........ (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

(Mrs.) Mary L. Sommerville - Infield, Alta. - Homemaker - Born Mar. 21, 1910.

George William Sommerville - Obermeyer, Sask. - Born May 21, 1902 - Farming on his own farm in the Kenora district. Attended University of Sask., 1921-23. Took up farming.

Mrs. Ethel May Sommerville - Vancouver, B.C. - Born Sept. 25, 1905. Married to Mr. G. H. Beal, who resides in Saskatchewan. She married her husband in 1947.

Lloyd Murray Sommerville - Obermeyer, Sask. - Born Aug. 24, 1906. Farming on his own farm.

Also have 10 grandchildren, and 3 great-grandchildren.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Higher education offered.

Rural electrification.

Mechanization of farming - tractors, combines, etc.

Electrical equipment in homes.

Question 40 (cont'd) - Of the ten grandchildren there are - 2 nurses, 1 teacher, 1 commercial artist, 1 C.C.A. pilot, 1 Road Commissioner worker, 1 University student, 1 High School student, 2 Public School students.
